messageBody:
Stephen Peterson wrote:
> At the risk of asking a dumb question ...
>
> Can someone elaborate more on why "Declared exceptions are a work
> of the devil"?
> What are declared exceptions in this context, and why are they so bad?
>
> thanks for your patience

See http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?CheckedExceptionsAreOfDubiousValue

Declared exceptions in this context are Java's checked exceptions.

The arguments against boil down to that it forces error-handling to be dealt
with explicitly or propagated upwards. This leads to objects have
dependencies on objects that they are not immediately related to (by 2 or
more degrees of separation). This is generally seen as a bad idea.

The arguments for boil down to that it forces error-handling to be dealt
with explicitly or propagated upwards. This improves the overall reliability
of the code in that at least the writer couldn't totally ignore the error
possibility. Of course, you end up with a lot of code like this:

try {
doSomethingThatCausesException();
}
catch (Exception e) {
}

but of course we wouldn't write code like that.

Tony's original message has a point in that Sun prefers unchecked exceptions
to be descended from java.lang.RuntimeException, reserving descendants of
java.lang.Error for fundamental problems.

Robert.
